titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Rose at 5. Walk before breakfast— Wrote letters in the forenoon— Spent the Evening at Mr: Cranch’s. While I was there Mr: and Mrs: Greenleaf came in; from Boston— They spend the winter here; at her father’s.— Mr: Whitney likewise called there— Weather very cold— Mrs: A. quite unwell yet.

2. Reaumur’s thermometer 7. degrees below 0 this morning, just before sun-rise— Took a walk— Mr: Black, and Mr: J. Gardiner called here this forenoon— Spent the day and evening in reading and writing— My wife has a very distressing cough.
3. Had a bad night— Mrs: A’s cough almost incessant. Continued most of this day.— Weather mild, and some rain. Walk’d round by Mr: Black’s and Gulliver’s brook— Wrote and read, but not to much use.

4. My wife continues ill with her cough; and this day was confined to her chamber.— I took a walk before breakfast— And again before dinner— Began to sort and file my letters received during my mission abroad— In the evening read to Mrs: A— part of Voltaire’s Œdipe.

5. Went to Boston with my Aunt Smith— Received at the loan office the certificates of my 8 per Ct: Stock. At Mr: Smith’s store and at his house— At Mr: Foster’s; conversed with him respecting furniture: but came to no determination— Dined at T. H. Perkins’s, with General Elliot and Major Frazier. W. Shaw came home with me in the Evening— My wife’s cold & cough continues very severe.
6 Heard Mr Whitney both parts of the day. Mr and Mrs. Cranch came home with us to tea— My uncle Adams and Captain Beale here to spend the Evening.—

7. A very cold day— Spent it entirely, from 4 in the morning till 9 at night in sorting the papers and letters received during the period of my mission to Europe. Got through the most laborious part of the work— Whitcomb went to Boston this morning.

8. Weather much moderated. Skaited this morning upon the Scotch pond— William Shaw return’d to Boston. We all went over to Weymouth, and dined at Dr: Tufts’s— His son, and Mr: Norton with their wives, and Mr: Brooks dined with us— Also Miss Hays a relation of Mrs: Tufts— Mrs: Norton came over to Quincy with my mother, after dinner— Employed still in sorting my old papers.

9. Took a long walk this forenoon, with my father, to a lot of land, call’d purgatory.— Weather very fine, and mild. My mother and wife paid visits in the forenoon. Took tea with them at Mrs: Cranch’s. Both Mrs: Norton and Mrs: Greenleaf there— Mr: Thayer called to visit us in the evening.— I continued arranging papers.

10. Somewhat unwell yesterday evening and in the night— Confined myself this day to the Office— Continued to put my papers in order, and wrote and read a little— Rain almost the whole day through— Cleared at Night.

11. Went to Boston this morning— To the house— Found little done, and much to do— To the post-office; gave letter for Mr: King to go by the ship, New Century. To Mr: Smith’s— Settled accts: with him and received of him a check upon the Union bank for $116:94. in full for the balance— At Quincy’s office— Judge Minot and he as a Committee of the charitable fire Society, requested me to deliver their annual discourse, next spring.— Consented— Dined at Mr: Foster’s— Brought home my Aunt Smith— Found our family gone to tea at Captain Beals— They soon however returned.— Day and evening cold.
12. Cold, clear day— Walk’d, half an hour before dinner— And in the afternoon, over to J. Gardner’s house— But he was gone in to Boston— Evening with the family.

13. Heard Mr: Pearce of Brookline, both parts of the day— He was here to tea— My uncle Adams, in the evening; and Miss Beale to see Louisa— My mother very ill— My wife’s cough still very severe— Finished making out the index to my files of papers received in Europe.

14. My mother continues very ill— Short walk after breakfast— Wrote letters to E. Randolph— Went with my wife to the house of Mr Quincy, to enquire for Dr: Tufts— He was not there— After dinner I walk’d over to Mr: Gardner’s at Milton, and pass’d a couple of hours with him— He has a son—born last week. He return’d with me part of the way.

15. Dr: Tufts this morning at Quincy— Came into Boston with Mrs: Adams and the child— She went out again in the afternoon— I remained in town and slept at the house.— We dined at Mr: Smith’s— Made sundry purchases for house-keeping.— W. Shaw was with me, part of the Evening.

16. Roused at 3 in the morning, by the bells, ringing for a fire— I rose and dress’d but did not go out. It burnt untill between 6 and 7 o’clock— About 15 dwelling houses; as many stores and shops, and three small vessels lying at the wharf.— Suspected to have been designedly kindled— I spent the day, chiefly in making purchases for my house, and preparing to move into it.— In the evening went with Mr: Smith, to the Wednesday evening club—at judge Minot’s— Home between 9 and 10.

17. Rose just after the Sun— Attended the sale of Dr: Rand’s furniture and purchased various articles. We were alarm’d again during the sale by a cry of fire; which was however soon extinguished— Continued to make various purchases for my house— My father came into Boston, to dine with the Mechanics.— I dined at home, and return’d with him to Quincy in the Evening— Found Mr: Hall, the schoolmaster, at the house.

18. Went with my wife down to Mr: Quincy’s house, and took some of the furniture— Dr: Tufts and his son with Mrs: Tufts and her niece were there— Dr: Tufts came with us, to dinner. Mr: John Greenleaf called in the Evening.— I was employed the greatest part of the day, in arranging papers; wishing if possible to commence the year, with my affairs in so much order as to be ready for any event that may happen.

19. Mrs: Adams had a bad night—and from one in the morning I had no rest— Still sorting old papers— Skaiting a couple of hours upon the Mill-pond— Very unskilful at this exercise, of which I suffered the penalties— Home at noon— Found Judge Davis, Genl: Elliot and Major Frazier come to invite my father to the anniversary feast on the 22d:— Dined with J. Gardner at Milton we were alone— He shewed me some of his old political speculations— Return’d home between 7. and 8. in the Evening.

20. Weather cold and clear— Skaited again an hour on the mill-pond, before breakfast— Heard Mr: Whitney, forenoon and afternoon— Pack’d some law books to go to Boston— Mrs: Cranch here at tea. My Uncle Adams came in afterwards— Arranging my papers again in the Evening.

21.— Winter solstice—the shortest day in the year.— Skaited upon the mill-pond, before breakfast. Came into Boston, with my wife and child, Epps and Lydia Pray, a maid-servant— Did something towards putting the house in order— Went out with Mrs: Adams and made some purchases— Mr: Smith and Mr: Jos: Hall called upon us—Mr: Parsons likewise— Evening at home—Backgammon, with Mrs: A.

22. Continuing the arrangement of the house— Find it difficult to procure money, either for exchange upon London, or for Stocks— Call’d at Mr: Smith’s store— At Mr: Foster’s shop— At Cleland’s Office &c— Spoke with J. Lowell junr: about an office he has to let— Met Dr: Welsh, and asked him to call on Mrs: Adams, whose cough and pain in the side are so violent that they alarm me. He bled her— But without obtaining relief— My Sister’s sons William and John came from Atkinson yesterday, and are upon their return home to New-York. They dined with Mrs: Adams— My father came into town, and with him I attended the feast, for celebrating the day when our forefathers landed at Plymouth— The dinner was at Concert-hall; and about 150 persons attended— Mr: S. Higginson presided— Mr: Pickering, Mr: Ames, Mr: Cabot &c were there— We had as usual toasts and songs— Between six and seven we retired— My father return’d to Quincy; taking William and John Smith with him— We had in the evening an alarm of fire, which however was soon over.— Play’d a game of piquet.— And early to-bed— Sent Whitcomb this afternoon to Quincy, to get the remainder of our goods there sent into Boston.

23. Mrs: Adams had a bad night— I rose at 3. o’clock— Read and wrote till breakfast time— Had Mr: Foster, and Mr: Osgood at work all day in the house— A Storm of rain the whole day— Three times at Cleland’s office without finding him— Whitcomb return’d from Quincy, and a Cart came in with some of our trunks and furniture— Very much fatigued at night, and very early to-bed.

24. A better night than the last; but Mrs: Adams continues very ill, with her cough and pain in the side— William and John Smith came into town from Quincy, and are to go on to-morrow morning, for New-York— Shipley came in with our goods from Quincy— Continuing purchases of furniture &c But, unable to procure money, either for stocks or for bills on London— Cleland at last lent me 300 dollars.— Called upon Hall—Quincy &c— My wife so unwell, I did not go out, after dinner.

25. Christmas day— Mrs: Adams seems to be somewhat better— She had several visitors in the forenoon. Mrs: Welsh and Charlotte—Mr: and Mrs: Quincy &c— I continued to provide furniture for my house— Mr: Jos: Hall, and W. Shaw, dined with us. T. Welsh called in the evening.— Hall stayed, in chat with us till 8 in the evening.

26. Mrs: Smith, & her sister Betsey, Mrs: Shaw, Stephen Higginson junr: and his wife called upon Mrs: Adams. Engaged an office in State-Street of J. Lowell— Subscribed for J. Russell’s Gazette— Met Mr: Smith in the market— And made some further purchases of furniture.— Richard came into town with the carriage. Mrs: Adams was too unwell to go out— I went out with W. Shaw— At Miss Eunice Payne’s, we took up my aunt Cranch— Got to Quincy, between 5 and 6 in the afternoon.

27. Dull weather, and rain’d great part of the day— Attended meeting, both parts of the day— Mr: M’Kean of Milton was the preacher— And in the morning inveighed against the practice of our churches in not celebrating Christmas day.— He likewise adopted much of his prayers from the forms of the prayer-book.— I pass’d the remainder of the day in arranging my papers— I have put up in one trunk all my files of letters-received as well before as since the year 1794.— And my old manuscripts in the draw of a desk— But some of my papers and manuscript books are missing.

28. Unpack’d one of the boxes of books sent from Berlin. Found several of the books much damaged— Came into Boston with W. Shaw— Dr: Welsh at our house, and Mrs: Adams very ill— Mr: W. Payne and his sisters, Mr: J. Gardiner and T. Welsh junr: call’d before dinner— Met Quincy walking in the afternoon— Evening at home— Mr: W. Smith called and pass’d an hour with us— An idle day, like most of the others of late.

29. Mrs: A— had a bad night, but this day has been better than for some time— I read and wrote a little. Beginning with Blackstone once more— Mr: J. Codman called to see me this afternoon, and W. Shaw spent an hour with us in the evening.

30. Mrs: A— appears rather better— But her most alarming complaint is not removed.— Marketed— Return’d visits to Mr: Babcock, Mr: G. Greene, Mr: Boylston, Mr: W. Payne, and Mrs: Shaw— The whole morning thus occupied. Read in the afternoon and evening, in the Voyage dans la Haute Pensylvanie.
31. Mrs: A— much better— She went this forenoon and return’d several visits— I was busied about many things; but none to much purpose— W. Shaw called here— Afternoon and evening at home.

Day. Part of the month spent at Quincy. The last ten days here— But the arrangements of moving, and settling to keep house have taken up all our time, and are not yet fully accomplished— I endeavour to establish the practice of early rising, not without various petty obstacles to prevent it—5 is the hour I fix for rising, but I must occasionally lose or gain an hour or two upon it— Before breakfast I prepare my accts: for the day preceding. And I have likewise employed an hour upon Mair’s Book-keeping— This art I never was taught, either at School, at College, or while a Student at Law— I have always kept Books, but for want of method and regularity they have not answered the purpose— I am undertaking to keep henceforth regular books, and am prepared to commence the New-Year in due form— At 9 we breakfast— From which time untill two, I have hitherto strolled about the town, marketing, making purchases or visiting— At two we dine— The afternoon and Evening I spend at home, reading or in conversation— Before 10. we go to bed.

At the close of this year, gratitude to Providence, for the blessings bestowed upon me in its course ought to be the first sentiment of my heart— Those blessings have been great and signal— The birth of my child, and the safe return of my family and myself to my Country and friends, are among the most conspicuous of them; And the unusual portion of health I have enjoyed is no less to be remembered with suitable acknowledgment— I am now returned to a private station and to my former profession— To begin the world anew, with the common chances of good or ill success.— I have only to implore the favour of Heaven for a continuance of health, and for the will and power to practice all the virtues which are calculated to promote the happiness of my fellow creatures, and my own. To that Providence I shall with full confidence, trust the event.
